title._content: The Remarkable Remains of a Recent Supernova

description._content: Description: A new Chandra observation is providing important details about the most recent supernova known to have exploded in the Milky Way. The explosion would have been visible from Earth a little more than a hundred years ago if it had not been heavily obscured by dust and gas. G1.9+0.3 was most likely created when a white dwarf star underwent a thermonuclear detonation and was destroyed - either after merging with another white dwarf or by pulling too much material from an orbiting companion star. The Chandra data show that most of the X-ray emission is "synchrotron radiation," produced by extremely energetic electrons accelerated in the rapidly expanding blast wave of the supernova. The new X-ray study also reveals that the explosion that created G1.9+0.3 was asymmetrical and unusually energetic. Creator: Chandra X-ray Observatory Center Date Created: 6/26/2013 Repository: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory Image ID: g19_xray Permanent URL: chandra.harvard.edu/photo/2013/g19/ View more collections from the Smithsonian Institution.
